Package mz

Class OddEvenMerge

java.lang.Object
mz.SortComparable
mz.Selection
mz.Bubble
mz.OddEven
mz.OddEvenMerge
All Implemented Interfaces:
MergeInterface<Comparable>, SelectionInterface<Comparable>, Sort<Comparable>, SortFind<Comparable>, SortSwap<Comparable>
Direct Known Subclasses:
BatcherOddEvenMerge, IntroOddEvenMerge
public class OddEvenMerge extends OddEven implements MergeInterface<Comparable>
Odd-even Merge Sort algorithm is a parallel sorting algorithm that is based on the concept of odd-even transposition sorting. It works by repeatedly comparing and swapping adjacent elements in pairs until the entire array is sorted.
Since:
1.0
Author:
Magyar Zolt√°n

  • Constructor Details

    • OddEvenMerge

      public OddEvenMerge()
      Odd-even Merge Sort:
      Example: Odd-even Merge Sort algorithm is a parallel sorting algorithm that is based on the concept of odd-even transposition sorting. It works by repeatedly comparing and swapping adjacent elements in pairs until the entire array is sorted.
      1. Divide the array: The array is divided into two halves. The odd-indexed elements are considered in the first half, and the even-indexed elements are considered in the second half.
      2. Sort the halves: Both halves are sorted independently using the same odd-even merge sort algorithm.
      3. Merge the sorted halves: The sorted halves are merged by comparing and swapping adjacent elements in pairs. The odd-indexed elements of the first half are compared with their corresponding even-indexed elements in the second half. If an element in the first half is greater than the corresponding element in the second half, they are swapped.
      4. Repeat until sorted: Steps 2 and 3 are repeated recursively until the entire array is sorted. This involves repeatedly dividing the array into halves, sorting them, and merging them back together.
      Note:
      The odd-even merge sort algorithm takes advantage of the parallelism available in certain hardware architectures, where pairs of adjacent elements can be compared and swapped simultaneously. By sorting and merging the odd and even elements separately, the algorithm exploits this parallelism and improves the sorting performance.

      It's important to note that the odd-even merge sort algorithm has a complexity of O(n^2) in the worst case, where n is the number of elements in the array. However, it can achieve better performance on parallel architectures due to its parallel nature.

      Stability: Odd-even merge sort is a stable sorting algorithm. This means that the relative order of elements with equal values is preserved after sorting. If two elements have the same value, the algorithm ensures that their original order is maintained in the sorted array.

      Property:
      Worst Case Complexity: O(n^2)
      Best Case Complexity: O(n^2)
      Average Case Complexity: O(n^2)
      Auxiliary Space: O(n)
      Stability: Yes
      See Also:
      • BatcherOddEvenMerge
      • IntroBatcherOddEvenMerge
      • IntroDPQBatcherOddEvenMerge
      • IntroDPQOddEvenMerge
      • IntroOddEvenMerge

    • oddEvenMergeInc

      protected void oddEvenMergeInc(Comparable[] array)
      oddEvenMergeInc takes an array of Comparable objects, along with the indices 0 and array.length indicating the range of elements to be sorted. The Odd-even Merge Sort algorithm. This algorithm is a parallel sorting algorithm that works by dividing the array into two halves, sorting them recursively, and then merging them back together.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to unchecked type casting when using the compareTo method. This annotation is not directly related to the functionality of the method but rather a way to handle warnings.
      • The variable n is initialized with the value of array.length, representing the number of elements to be sorted in the current recursion. If n is less than or equal to 1, the method returns, as there is no need to sort an array with 0 or 1 element.
      • The variable mid is set to (n / 2), representing the midpoint of the current range.
      • Two new arrays, oddHalf and evenHalf, are created using Arrays.copyOfRange. oddHalf contains the elements from index 0 to (mid - 1) of the original array, and evenHalf contains the elements from index mid to (n - 1).
      • The oddEvenMergeInc method is recursively called on both oddHalf and evenHalf to sort them.
      • A loop iterates from 0 to (mid - 1). For iteration, it compares the element at index i with the element at index (i + mid) in the original array. If the element at index i is greater than the element at index (i + mid), a swap method is called to swap the two elements.
      Finally, the mergingInc method is called with the original array, oddHalf, and evenHalf as arguments to merge the two sorted halves back into the original array.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      See Also:
      • SortSwap.swap(Comparable[], int, int)
      • MergeInterface.mergingInc(Comparable[], Comparable[], Comparable[])

This algorithm is a parallel sorting algorithm that works by dividing the array into two halves, sorting them recursively, and then merging them back together.

    • oddEvenMergeInc

      protected void oddEvenMergeInc(Comparable[] array, int left, int right)
      oddEvenMergeInc takes an array of Comparable objects, along with the indices left and right indicating the range of elements to be sorted. The Odd-even Merge Sort algorithm. This algorithm is a parallel sorting algorithm that works by dividing the array into two halves, sorting them recursively, and then merging them back together.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to unchecked type casting when using the compareTo method. This annotation is not directly related to the functionality of the method but rather a way to handle warnings.
      • The variable n is initialized with the value of right, representing the number of elements to be sorted in the current recursion. If n is less than or equal to 1, the method returns, as there is no need to sort an array with 0 or 1 element.
      • The variable mid is set to (n / 2), representing the midpoint of the current range.
      • Two new arrays, oddHalf and evenHalf, are created using Arrays.copyOfRange. oddHalf contains the elements from index 0 to (mid - 1) of the original array, and evenHalf contains the elements from index mid to (n - 1).
      • The oddEvenMergeInc method is recursively called on both oddHalf and evenHalf to sort them.
      • A loop iterates from left to (mid - 1). For iteration, it compares the element at index i with the element at index (i + mid) in the original array. If the element at index i is greater than the element at index (i + mid), a swap method is called to swap the two elements.
      Finally, the mergingInc method is called with the original array, oddHalf, and evenHalf as arguments to merge the two sorted halves back into the original array.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - specific range of the array.
      right - specific range of the array.

    • oddEvenMergeDec

      protected void oddEvenMergeDec(Comparable[] array, int left, int right)
      oddEvenMergeDec takes an array of Comparable objects, along with the indices left and right indicating the range of elements to be sorted. The Odd-even Merge Sort algorithm. This algorithm is a parallel sorting algorithm that works by dividing the array into two halves, sorting them recursively, and then merging them back together.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to unchecked type casting when using the compareTo method. This annotation is not directly related to the functionality of the method but rather a way to handle warnings.
      • The variable n is initialized with the value of right, representing the number of elements to be sorted in the current recursion. If n is less than or equal to 1, the method returns, as there is no need to sort an array with 0 or 1 element.
      • The variable mid is set to (n / 2), representing the midpoint of the current range.
      • Two new arrays, oddHalf and evenHalf, are created using Arrays.copyOfRange. oddHalf contains the elements from index 0 to (mid - 1) of the original array, and evenHalf contains the elements from index mid to (n - 1).
      • The oddEvenMergeDec method is recursively called on both oddHalf and evenHalf to sort them.
      • A loop iterates from left to (mid - 1). For iteration, it compares the element at index i with the element at index (i + mid) in the original array. If the element at index i is smaller than the element at index (i + mid), a swap method is called to swap the two elements.
      Finally, the mergingDec method is called with the original array, oddHalf, and evenHalf as arguments to merge the two sorted halves back into the original array.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - specific range of the array.
      right - specific range of the array.
